content: I recall some very similar clash a long time ago, albeit simpler.

Thank you for your feedback. Here are the changes I made:

 - Moved some of the XOR properties at the end of the statement, in a "for your curiosity" category, since this information is not necessary to complete the clash.

 - Renamed the variable in the stub generator that were previously called mess, key and encrypted. They gave too much information for reverse mode so they are now called m, k and e.

 - Changed Test 1 and Test 2 to single bit key so that you get a better idea of what is happening. This made reverse mode easier but still challenging.

 - Modified all the validators to have the same message length and key length than the tests. This should prevent a 100% score on tests but a different score on validators (which is frankly the most frustrating thing ever in CoC).

I can't wait to tackle the golf version of this ^^
Nicely written, though the statement is a bit long for CoC. Maybe the sentence "In mathematics (...)" could be removed (no interest).
Could be really fun in reverse mod.

The problem statement is very clear and explains the topic well. It's also definitely suitable for reverse mode :)

I would suggest a couple changes to the tests:
 - Validator 2 is the only case where the key consists completely of 0. Perhaps make this its own test case?
 - Test 2 could have its key swapped so that it doesn't match Test 1 (10 instead of 01)
 - Maybe you could add test cases with single-bit messages or single-bit keys.
 - Validator 5 should match Test 5 (ie the message and key should be the same length)
Thank you for those suggestions, I tried to satisfy all of them. It's definitely better this way
Moved it a bit further in the statement with a "for your curiosity" header so that you can skip this information easily and understand quickly that you don't need it
Ok, then the instructions "You will be given..." should be before that part (and should probably be emphasized in some way, e.g. bold font).
Alright, moved it again and made the statement more compact and concise. This should help understanding the problem faster
